comments: Live virtual seminar once per week for ~2hrs.
NA

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Deep, intimate introduction to neoliberalism and its manifestations in a capitalist society. Extensive interaction with content regarding sexuality, gender, societal structures that impact people and their expression. Intense questioning of the societies we live in, the people in power, the history that brought us here, and the systems and structures that decide who gets to live what life.

So much! I learned about many different dimensions of the relationship between neoliberalism and sexuality, particularly as it relates to institutions such as the family, marriage, the police, and so on.
I learned how to read and analyze articles that dealt with the theory and how to collaboratively break down these articles with my peers.

gosh what didnt i learn from this course. i learned about the different facets of neoliberalism and how they pervade every aspect of society. even things that we think are forward thinking really arent because they have some tinge of neoliberalism.

I learned how to think critically about current structures in our society and how to evaluate the ways that these structures impact various groups and populations, esp. those populations that are marginalized and oppressed by the structures that exist under neoliberal capitalism.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this course. The readings are long but enjoyable, challenging, and insightful. You learn a lot about how capitalism and freedom structure the world and decide who gets to live what life.

This course is absolutely amazing. The readings are dense but fascinating, and we always cover them in depth through lively and engaging discussions in class. The assignments are very manageable and give you the opportunity to bring your own perspective to the topics of the class. Hard to name something to improve!

Strengths: Professor Savci is an amazing professor who makes everyone feel welcome to contribute to our discussions. This was my first WGSS course and I did not feel intimidated at all be because of Professor Savci's ability to break down what we were learning into ideas we could all understand. 
Weaknesses: None.
strengths is evren. she is the most incredible professor. everything she says is pure genius. there are no weaknesses to this class. its incredible.

great facilitation of discussion, great questions posed to students, welcoming environment, learned so much, amazing readings. Would love to add a discussion section or just more time for discussion, felt like I didn't get to talk about the readings enough.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course went so smoothly even in a virtual format! Our seminar-style discussions on Zoomwith short, much-appreciated breaksworked well. I also enjoyed posting on the class blog and reading through/commenting on others' posts.
i think evren was exceptionally understanding in terms of students mental health and was so accommodating. i wish more professors were like her in this time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Prof. Savci is incredible. She makes the seminar format impeccably effective and thorough, and promotes an atmosphere like no other. The course is insightful, challenging, and a great way to test what you think you know about the world and life.

Absolutely! This course will fundamentally change the way you think about the social, political, and economic implications of... basically everything. I think it's also a great course for folks who want to dip their toes into WGSS.

Yes! This class was a great introduction to WGSS courses and was super interesting and engaging. I found myself using what I had learned in this class to help me with assignments in my other classes. Everything we learned was very relevant.
yea, i would. you will literally rethink your entire worldview. and sound so smart when you critique systems of power because you will know what youre talking about.

I cannot recommend this course enough to other students. It approaches a really important theoretical formation with a particular attention to the role of desire and sexuality. While these discussions could get lost in the cloud of theory, the course material grounds the class in everyday life, which enlivens the discussion even more. Overall, a wonderful and intellectually stimulating class on a complex topic.
Definitely.
Yes, one of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale! You will learn so much, read interesting things, and get to know a fantastic prof.
